title: 105_hr1560
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Lewis and Clark Expedition Bicentennial Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress acknowledges the significant achievements of the Lewis and Clark Expedition, also known as "The Corps of Discovery", which greatly advanced geographical knowledge of the continent in response to President Jefferson's directive. The Lewis and Clark Expedition greatly advanced geographical knowledge of the continent by exploring the newly acquired Louisiana territory and interacting with American Indian tribes. The Expedition departed from St. Louis, Missouri, in May 1804, met with American Indians at Council Bluff, wintered at Fort Mandan in North Dakota, crossed the Rocky Mountains, and wintered at Fort Clatsop in Oregon before returning to St. Louis. The Lewis and Clark Expedition returned to St. Louis, Missouri on September 23, 1806, after a 28-month journey covering 8,000 miles and traversing 11 future states. The expedition enhanced knowledge of the western continent, improved relationships with American Indian nations, and is considered a diplomatic success. The Lewis and Clark Expedition is hailed as the most perfect expedition in history, paving the way for the US to become a world power. The Lewis and Clark Expedition paved the way for the US to become a world power. SEC. 3 outlines coin specifications. The bicentennial of the Lewis and Clark expedition will be commemorated by minting $1 coins and half dollar coins with specific weights, diameters, and silver-copper composition. These coins will be legal tender as per section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. All coins minted under this title shall be considered numismatic items according to section 5134 of title 31, United States Code. The Secretary will only obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be determined as per the regulations. The coins minted under this title shall be emblematic of the Lewis and Clark expedition, with inscriptions of value, years 1804-1806, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The obverse of each coin will feature Thomas Jefferson, Meriwether Lewis, and William Clark, with elements from the Jefferson Peace and Friendship Medal considered in the design. The Jefferson Peace and Friendship Medal was presented by Lewis and Clark to Indian Chiefs, and there are plans to recognize Native American culture. The design for the coins will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this title shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting on January 1, 2003, with minting authority ending on December 31, 2003.

SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this title will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount on sale prices. Surcharges for coins minted under this title are $10 per $1 coin and $7 per half dollar coin. SEC. 8. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this title, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Proceeds from surcharges on coin sales under this title are divided between the National Lewis and Clark Bicentennial Council and the National Park Service for bicentennial activities. Recipients are subject to audit requirements. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 10. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can only be issued if payment is received, security is provided, or a guarantee of payment is given by a qualified institution. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
